title: Paying for performance: Realized pay and performance in CEO careers, an examination of outcomes.
abstractText:
This study will follow Chief Executive Officers (CEOs) of large companies over their entire career as CEO.  By measuring their realised pay and the performance of their company over this period, a clear and unambiguous picture will emerge of the connection between the pay and performance of the UK’s top executives.

In addition, the study will also look at whether externally appointed CEOs extract more favourable remuneration terms than internal promotions; whether the termination payments received by exiting CEOs are ‘fair’; if the use of arrangements such as share options successfully hold executives in place (as often claimed); and if companies change the way they reward their new CEO in the light of experience with the previous CEO.

While all of these questions are of interest in their own context (that of the executive labour market), they also have implications for the way in which the labour market more generally works.  A considerable amount of effort is made to arrange the way people are paid so as to provide incentives and to ensure a loyalty in employment.  The pay and career paths of CEOs offer a useful set of data with which to scrutinise such ideas.
